page.title: 14HOUSING IN CASTLE CARROCK
page.content: Most of the 84 houses in central CASTLE CARROCK were built in the 18th and 19th centuries. Sandstone was quarried locally and slate was brought from the Lake District. Along the main road leading to Carlisle are several typical inter-war semi-detached houses; while on the minor road leading to the fells are 5 detached bungalows built in the 1960s. Since then the only changes have been the erection of 3 new detached in-fill properties, the conversion of 3 old barns, courtyard buildings and a wing of Gelt Hall into modern houses and flats. Although all 84 properties are occupied, two are "second homes". Most properties are owner-occupied, and even most of the few Council houses have been bought by their tenants.
